div.head: Statistics on variant types and subtypes
div.p: These are some statistics on variant types, generated dynamically by my Python script statistics.py, that processes the XML code of the edition:

list.item:
Total 'app' elements: 4817, of which:
1786 have @type="substantive"
156 @type="transposition" (note that each transposition is recorded in two 'app's, so the actual number of transpositions is 78)
1662 @type="orthographic". However, this number includes 'app's with @type="orthographic" and @subtype="case", which are no actual MS variants (see paragraph 'Case variants' above). If we subtract them from 1662, the total of actual MS orthographic variants excluding case is 1524
15 @type="gap-in-ms"
14 @type="illegible-in-ms"
1184 @type="punctuation"

The actual variants are 3388. In this number
I count types "substantive", "transposition" (counted once, henceforth) and "orthographic" (except @subtype="case")
I do not count types "punctuation", "gap-in-ms", "illegible-in-ms", or the special case @type="orthography"/@subtype="case"

Of all actual variants (V):
52.7% are substantive (SV henceforth) 45.0% are orthographic (not counting @subtype="case"; OVEC henceforth) 2.3% are transpositions

The following subtypes have been identified for substantive variants (@type="substantive"):
210, i.e. 6.2% of all actual variants (V), have @subtype 'missing-in-ms' (integrations)
88 (2.6% of V) have @subtype 'num-num' (two different numerals)
75 (2.2% of V) have @subtype 'missing-in-print' (expunctions)
10 (0.3% of V) have @subtype 'fs' (confusion between 'f' and 's')

A @subtype has been identified for 408 substantive 'app's. This corresponds to 22.8% of all substantial variants (SV) and 12.0% of all actual variants (V)

A @subtype has been identified for 1101 orthographic 'app's. This corresponds to 72.2% of all orthographic variants (OVEC) and 32.5% of all actual variants (V) (I am not including 'app's with @subtype="case" in these calculations)
There is no subtype of type "transposition"
So, including both substantive and orthographic variants (except @subtype="case"), for 1509 'app's a @subtype has been identified, corresponding to 44.5% of all actual variants (V)

The typization of variants was an experimental feature of this digital edition. A higher percentage of subtypes could be identified, especially for orthographic variants, by further improving the string comparison algorithms used, but these initial results seem encouraging. Please keep in mind that algorithms (Python software) tentatively identified types and subtypes for app elements, then I reviewed them one by one manually. However, the more accurate the algorithms became, the easier and quicker the review was.

div.head: Statistics on textual-critical decisions
div.p: Out of a total of 3388 'actual' loci variantes (V, as defined above):

list.item: In 2971 cases (87.7% of V) I agreed with the reading of the print edition used as collation exemplar (Garufi or Bonetti)
In 417 cases (12.3% of V) I chose a MS reading over that of the print edition

As for the utility of witness O in this edition: in only 4 cases O is the only witness providing a reading that I chose over the print edition reading. This corresponds to 1.0% of all loci variantes in which O is one of the witnesses. Although this calculation is based on a subjective parameter (i.e. my own textual choices), this is an argument against the actual utility of O for the constitutio textus of the Chronicon.
